title: Why does the mass of an object increase when its speed increases? - Quora

response.answer_text: The actual mass DOES NOT increase with speed. What increases it the RELATIVISTIC mass which is not the actual mass. The relativistic mass is instead a convenient mathematical construct that allows you to apply classic newtonian physics formulas to objects that move at very fast speeds (close enough to the speed of light) from your frame of reference. It is true that as an object goes faster and faster and approach the speed of light you need more and more energy to achieve the same acceleration … AS IF it weighs more and more but the actual weight is not increasing here. Instead this change in the amount of energy that you need to increase its speed just another of those quirky effects of getting that object closer to the speed of light including time dilatation and space contraction. Note that the an observer in within the object that is accelerating to the speed of light won’t ever feel a difference (that is the core of the relativity theory) and in fact from his point of view the amount of energy expend from within his frame of reference (eg. is a rocket properled vehicle) is exacty the same…. but since his clock is ticking slower that your clock from your prespective the engergy he is expending per second is much lower and his acceleration is actually dicreasing… which is compatible with your impression that more energy is required to keep the same acceleration. It all works out in the end without any change in actual mass. As a separate note some of the other answer that state that the actual mass actually change the use the E=mc^2 as proving such statement … if E increase also des m…. but this is formula give you an equivalence between E and m … ie if you were to transform all that E into m or viceversa (if you actually able to do that). It does not give you a correlation between the two nor an increase or decrease of those two like some answer implied If you have a USD bank account and you put 100$ in it you clould transform it in a GBP account with 80 Sterling Pounds. That is not the same as you have 2 bank accounts one in USD another in GBP and if you put 100$ in the USD all in a sudden 80 Pounds appear in the other one. Got it?

Does mass increase with speed? Einstein showed that the effective or relativistic mass increased with speed in direct proportion to its Lorentz factor and its energy. “Mass” has recently been defined to include only the rest mass. This is the “mass” in the rest frame, which by definition has a velocity of zero. In this frame, the Lorentz factor is one, and the relativistic mass equals the rest mass. Special relativity deals only with predicting what would be measured between uniformly moving reference frames. What is measured is precisely what is predicted by the Lorentz transformation. The flaws with special relativity are in the ways scientists interpret those predicted measurements. You repeatedly read that the moving particles “experience” length contraction and time dilation. Nothing could be further from the truth. Time and space are perfectly normal in all moving rest frames. Length contraction and time dilation are what we would measure. They change with our velocity relative to it. The moving particle “experiences” none of it. Miss-interpretation of special relativity leads to false conclusions. For example: (1) Einstein’s special relativity predicted that the mass that would be measured increases proportionally to the Lorentz factor. That measured mass is the “relativistic mass.” It is the mass that should be used in previous equations of physics that depend on the mass property. These include Newton’s second principle, the equation for momentum, Newton’s equation of gravitation, Einstein’s famous mass-energy equivalence equation, and the general relativity field equations. If you don’t know this, your predictions for high-speed physics will be wrong, not because special relativity is wrong, but because you don’t know how to apply it.
